question: What metamorphic rock forms when limestone is compacted, heated, and recrystallized?

content.source_1: Metamorphic rocks form when pre-existing rocks are subjected to heat and pressure that compact the rock and drive recrystallization of minerals, without the rock fully melting.
content.source_2: Limestone is a sedimentary carbonate rock composed mainly of calcite (CaCO3).
content.source_3: Marble forms when limestone is metamorphosed; the calcite grains recrystallize into an interlocking mosaic, producing marble.
content.source_4: In contact metamorphism, limestone or dolostone adjacent to a magma intrusion can be heated and infiltrated by silica-rich hydrothermal fluids; metasomatic reactions and recrystallization can convert the carbonate rock into calc-silicate skarn.
content.source_5: Skarn is a metamorphic rock distinct from marble, characterized by calc-silicate minerals such as garnet, pyroxene, and wollastonite, formed by chemical replacement of carbonate rocks during contact metamorphism.
content.source_6: The metamorphic product of carbonate rocks depends on chemistry: relatively pure limestone recrystallizes to marble, whereas interaction with abundant silica (either as impurities or via introduced fluids) can produce skarn instead of marble.
